text: feedback: would it be possible to move all the existing design manager templates/files into it's own folder when moving to the new design manager? Most of the portals I'm working in have an extremely messy file/folder structure that's more apparent than ever with the new designer manager's finder. It'd be nice to have a "clean slate" to work with to make things easier to find. Or at least have a way to differentiate new modules from the old modules in the finder. Keep up the great work!

Hi Stefen! You could try creating a new folder (perhaps something like ‘v1 assets’) and drag all of the existing files into it. There should only be a handful of existing parent folders (templates, coded files, custom modules, global content).
that's a good idea. I was kind of assuming we couldn't move the root folders since we were limited in the existing design manager to only control the sub folders.

I believe that you can. However, I would hold off on doing so until you’re sure that you’ll never have to copy a v1 template to another portal, as v1 always followed the structure-by-type (custom modules were always in the ‘custom modules’ folder).
ah, makes sense. thanks for the tips.
No problem! Feel free to ping me if you have any questions or run into any other issues.

for example, here is a portal that i just enabled the new design manager on, and there are a bunch of strange folders like "default_module", "root", and "Defaults_-_Don't_Delete", etc.. that don't actually have anything in them. Any idea what these are and if it's safe to delete them?
A file, which can't be shown because your team is past the free storage limit, was commented on.
Here’s what I did - I created a new folder - title it something like “old” and moved all of the folders inside of that except root
I also created a new folder and did all my design manager v2 stuff in there
is anybody having issue with the module changes not being applied? I mean not seeng the changes on a live page
Can you provide an example? You can direct message me if you’d like.

Jeff I think this is a good example template (<https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/template/multi?is_buffered_template_layout=true&portalId=4076345&tc_deviceCategory=desktop&template_layout_id=5555729903>). Notice the quality difference between the header image and footer image? One of them was added via HubL at the template level and adding ?noresize to the end of the default url. The header image was swapped in the email editor to a different image using the image module and it clearly has lower quality. I can use that exact same header image URL at the template level as the default image and it is super crisp just like the footer image.
to me the header image looks a lot better than the footer image. The text is hard to read in the footer. These are tough because they’re so subjective. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
